channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed
channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed

item.title: Marvel Rivals Fans Are Ready To Curbstomp Jeff The Land Shark
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/marvel-rivals-jeff-the-land-shark-ultimate-ability-1851716962

Marvel Rivals launched last week, and as fans are flocking to the game in droves, they’re also figuring out who their favorite and least favorite characters are on the hero shooter’s roster. Right now, the game feels like it’s in the pre-patch state of just being a real chaotic shooter that hasn’t yet been sanded down by months of balance patches. Currently, few characters are as chaotic as Jeff the Land Shark, the strategist hero who is, at a glance, just a silly little guy. However, as Marvel Rivals players have learned, this happy dude is actually one of the biggest menaces in the game, and god, I hope NetEase keeps him like this forever.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

Jeff is a “strategist,” the Marvel Rivals equivalent of a support hero. Most of the time he sprays water from his mouth to patch up teammates and leaves healing-infused bubbles around the battlefield for players to walk through and recover some of their HP. However, it’s his ultimate that has become the bane of most players’ existence. “It’s Jeff!” creates a sizable whirlpool on the battlefield, which Jeff circles before devouring any player inside the area of effect. From here, he can do one of a few things. He can chew on them as he swims around, doing small damage over time. He can spit them out, displacing them. Or, he can do what most players have learned to do and send them off the side of the map.

At first, my experience with hungry Jeffs was that players would swallow several opponents and then spit them off the map and into a chasm. As a Star-Lord main, this was usually not that big of a deal, as I could just fly right back to safety. However, as more players have used this strategy, Jeff players have wised up and realized that they’ll get more value diving off the side of the map themselves while their foes are still trapped than they will by just spitting them out and risking them returning to safety. It has become such a foolproof strategy that seemingly every Jeff player is utilizing it, and everyone else wants the land shark’s blood.

While that’s the most common strategy now, sometimes there isn’t a hole nearby, and some players are using Jeff’s ultimate as a way to throw a team off an objective or to set up other more devastating attacks, like grouping together several foes to toss them into Scarlet Witch’s explosive ultimate. Whatever strategy Jeff players are using, the character’s destructive power contrasted with his cute, unassuming demeanor has made him the center of so many jokes in the game’s community just days after launch.

We still don’t know how NetEase will balance Marvel Rivals in the future, but there’s part of me that hopes it stays this messy, unpolished hero shooter and “unfair,” “toxic” nonsense like Jeff’s ultimate stays in the game. Ultimately, it’ll hinge on what the studio wants for the game. Does it want Marvel Rivals to become a big esports sensation or does it want to keep appealing to the casual player who isn’t getting sweaty and just wants to slam their superhero toys against each other? The latter is preferable to me at this point, and the chaos of Jeff the Land Shark is one of the best examples of it.

item.title: Fortnite is Developing an Extraction Shooter Gamemode, It’s Claimed
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/fortnite-is-developing-an-extraction-shooter-gamemode/

New leaks suggest that Epic Games and Fortnite are working on a new extraction shooter gamemode.

The news comes from Fortnite leaker and data miner Loolo_WRLD on X (formerly Twitter), who revealed that despite some rumors suggesting that the game mode is canceled, it is, in fact, still in development.

While it’s unclear what the game would entail in the Fortnite universe, it will likely follow almost every other extraction shooter in the market with its game loop. Drop into a map, gather resources, extract, and repeat.

Loolo_WRLD was careful to point out that “things might change,” as is the case with all leaks, so we’ll have to wait and see if the gamemode comes to fruition.

According to leakers, the game mode is currently under development under the codename “Arnold.”

Last week, new rumors surfaced that Fortnite OG Has Up to 90% Bots Per Game for lower-skilled players. Epic Games has yet to comment officially on the addition of bots and skill-based matchmaking in Fortnite, but if there is an official announcement, we’ll be sure to update this article.

What do you think of Fortnite trying out the extraction shooter genre? Let us know down below, and join more discussions in the official Insider Gaming forums.

For more Insider Gaming, read about the new hire making his way to Naughty Dog. And don’t forget to sign up for our newsletter.

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: Is Counter-Strike Only on PC?
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/is-counter-strike-only-on-pc/

Counter-Strike is one of the most iconic PC titles in the history of gaming. The definitive first-person tactical shooter is synonymous with PC gaming, and has been since the first game released in 2000. Even now, following the release of Counter-Strike 2 in 2023, the series is still a dominant force on computers.

Many multiplayer shooters find success appealing to player bases outside of PC though. Has Counter-Strike finally done the same?

Is Counter-Strike Only on PC?

Counter-Strike 2 has only been officially released on PC. The lack of an official version for players on Mac is surprising, given that the game’s predecessor Counter-Strike: Global Offensive did in fact have official Mac support. CS2 is “playable” on Mac, but not in an official capacity.

CS2 is not available on any console either, though CS:GO still appears to be playable on the older generation. CS:GO released for Xbox 360 and PS3 when it came out in 2013. CS:GO was replaced by CS2 on PC when the current game launched last year, but the Xbox 360 version remains online, at least as recently as September 2023.

The game is also playable on Steam Deck, but it is not optimized for Valve’s handheld device. The CS2 Steam Deck compatibility rating states that it shows mouse and keyboard icons, as well as small in-game text that may be difficult to read on a smaller screen.

CS2’s launch without a console version indicates that it is probably not a huge priority for Valve at this time. However, Valve’s competitor Riot eventually released a console version of VALORANT years after its launch, so it wouldn’t be unheard of if Valve did the same.

Do you wish CS2 would come out on something else than PC? Let us know in the Insider Gaming forum.

Stay tuned to Insider Gaming for the latest esports news. And don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: Palworld ditches Pokéball-style summoning mechanic amid Nintendo legal battle
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/palworld-ditches-pokeball-style-summoning-mechanic-amid-nintendo-legal-battle

Palworld developer Pocket Pair has released an update for the creature-catching survival game removing the ability to summon creatures by throwing Pokéball-style Pal Spheres - all as its continues to fight Nintendo and The Pokémon Company's patent infringement lawsuit.

As detailed in Palworld's brisk v0.3.11 patch notes, Pocket Pal's latest update means it's no longer possible to summon a captured creature to a specific spot by aiming and throwing a Pal Sphere. Instead, Pals are now summoned directly next to players when Pal Spheres are held out. Additionally, the UI reticle is now only displayed while aiming.

Although Pocket Pair is yet to provide a reason for the changes, it's notable the update arrives amid the studio's ongoing legal battle with Nintendo and The Pokémon Company. Nintendo announced it was suing Pocket Pair for infringement of "multiple" patents back in September, and it was later confirmed the lawsuit is targeting three patents in particular. These primarily cover throwing an object in a specific direction to either summon a battle character or to capture a creature in the field - mechanics Palworld shared with Pokémon at launch.

Nintendo is seeking an injunction against Palworld, as well as a fine of 10m yen (around £50k), and "late payment damages". However, Pocket Pair has vowed to fight Nintendo's claims, insisting it would "continue to assert our position in this case through future legal proceedings". There's been no official confirmation today's changes are related to the lawsuit, but Eurogamer has contacted Pocket Pair for comment.

Regardless, Palworld's development continues, and Pocket Pair has teased it'll have some sort of presence during this week's The Game Awards. "You won’t want to miss it!", the studio wrote in a message shared on social media.

item.title: When Does Path of Exile 2 Become Free to Play?
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/when-does-path-of-exile-2-become-free-to-play/

Path of Exile 2, Grinding Games’ latest action RPG, was going to be a free-to-play title. However, you need to pay $30 to play the game in early access right now. So when does Path of Exile 2 actually become free-to-play? The short answer is when the developers decide to remove it from early access. 

When Does Path of Exile 2 Early Access End? 

Currently, there is no concrete end date for Path of Exile 2’s early access. However, the developers have provided an estimated period in the game’s FAQ section. The answer to how long the early access will run is “As long as needed, we expect at least 6 months.” 

According to the developers’ estimated window, Path of Exile 2 will seemingly become free to play by June 2025. However, this is not a confirmed window, and as the developers have stated, “as long as needed,” they could take longer or even finish earlier. 

At the moment, you must pay a minimum of $30 to play Path of Exile 2’s early access on Steam, Epic Games Store, PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S. Check out where to play the game in early access here. 

In other news, Path of Exile 2 has doubled the all-time player peak of the original game while being in early access. Also, check out the game’s cross-platform and cross-progression details. What are your thoughts on Path of Exile 2 taking 6 more months to become free-to-play?  Let us know in the comments or our community forum!

Before you head off, check out our guide on everything we know about Path of Exile 2. It’s full of helpful information, like the system requirements and more!

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: PS5 DualSense Hall Effect Stick Replacements Now Available
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps5-dualsense-hall-effect-stick-replacements-now-available/1100-6528320/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There’s a lot to love about the PS5 DualSense controller, but there’s also one big oversight--it doesn’t use Hall Effect joysticks. That means it can--and often does--succumb to joystick drift over time, which is less than ideal for a $75 gamepad. Thankfully, Hyperkin has just released a PS5 Hall Effect Joystick Replacement Kit, allowing you to replace both sticks for just $16. They’re proving to be wildly popular (Amazon is temporarily out of stock), but you can still place orders while waiting for inventory to replenish.

Hyperkin PS5 Hall Effect Joystick Replacement Kit

$16

Before picking up this cool replacement kit, be warned that the installation process is a bit involved. The main hurdle is soldering, though you’ll also have to use a screwdriver to calibrate its positioning. That means novice modders should steer clear of this operation or ensure they have a professional game shop nearby that can help with the installation.

Hyperkin's replacement joysticks are rated for 5 million rotations and thanks to the way the Hall Effect sensors work, they won't drift over time like the DualSense's base sticks can. At just $16, these are a much wiser investment than buying a new controller--assuming you have the necessary skill to install them.

If you don't wat to wait for Hyperkin's PS5 joystick replacement kit to restock, another option is the AKNES GuliKit TMR Electromagnetic Joystick Replacement Kit, which is currently in stock and available for $18. It's available in PS5 and Xbox Series X versions, and just like Hyperkin's Hall Effect sticks kit, the GuilKit TMR joystick replacements will require soldering and careful installation. TMR Electromagnetic joysticks are similar to Hall Effect sticks, but they’re typically more sensitive and often seen as having a slight advantage over Hall Effect. You can't go wrong with either, as both types of technology are leagues ahead of their analog counterparts.

If you're in the market for a new DualSense controller, several colors are currently on sale, including Midnight Black for just $54 (was $75). You’ll find all the best DualSense deals below.

Best DualSense Deals

  • Midnight Black -- $54 ($75)
  • White -- $54 ($75)
  • Chroma Indigo -- $59 ($80)
  • Chroma Pearl -- $54 ($80)
  • Cobalt Blue -- $59 ($80)
  • Cosmic Red -- $54 ($75)
  • Volcanic Red -- $59 ($80)
  • Sterling Silver -- $59 ($80)

  • The Legend Of Zelda Metal Puzzles Restocked At Amazon - Still On Sale For Only $15

item.title: God of War art director Raf Grassetti joins Naughty Dog after Netflix studio's collapse
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/art/god-of-war-art-director-raf-grassetti-joins-naughty-dog-to-start-a-new-chapter-

Image via Sony Santa Monica/PlayStation.

Raf Grassetti, the art director for Sony Santa Monica's (SSM) recent God of War duology, has found himself back at PlayStation after Netflix's big studio closure. On X (formerly Twitter), he revealed he's started a "new chapter" at fellow A-list developer Naughty Dog.

Grassetti departed SSM last year after he'd spent "over a decade" at the God of War developer. Weeks later, he revealed he was joining Netflix Games' then-burgeoning studio focused on creating triple-A titles. Codenamed Team Blue, it included fellow industry alums Joe Staten (Halo) and Chacko Sonny (Overwatch), and its team was developing an original project for PC and consoles.

This past October, Netflix closed Team Blue in a layoff wave which affected 35 employees. The developer was a notable startup for the streamer, as it had mainly been acquiring pre-existing indie studios like Spry Fox and Next Games up to Blue's founding in 2022.

It's unclear at this time where Sonny and Staten have ended up after Team Blue's shutdown.

What's going on with Naughty Dog?

Earlier this year Naughty Dog released a PlayStation 5 remake of The Last of Us Part II. But with its live-service spinoff for that franchise dead, it remains a mystery as to what the famed developer is working on next.

In February, PlayStation laid off 900 employees across its various first-party teams and cancelled multiple projects. Naughty Dog was among those studios impacted, as were Insomniac Games and Guerilla Games.

Still, studio head Neil Druckmann revealed in June that Naughty Dog is working on several single-player projects. While the studio has said little about these games, at least one of them will feature Troy Baker—a frequent Naughty Dog collaborator—in some capacity.

About the Author

Contributing Editor, GameDeveloper.com

A Kansas City, MO native, Justin Carter has written for numerous sites including IGN, Polygon, and SyFy Wire. In addition to Game Developer, his writing can be found at io9 over on Gizmodo. Don't ask him about how much gum he's had, because the answer will be more than he's willing to admit.

item.title: Forever Skies Co-op Launch Available Today, Huge Overhaul Added in New Update
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/forever-skies-co-op-launch-available-today-huge-overhaul-added-in-new-update/

As of today, the co-op update for Forever Skies is officially out and will allow players to group up in teams of four to explore the vast world that the game has to offer. All PC players will be able to play together with the co-op update, where you can work together to gather supplies, fight for survival, and help build up a fully customizable airship to help each other survive on the toxic, post-apocalyptic Earth. For those interested in the game, Far From Home is offering a limited-time discount on Forever Skies on Steam until January 2.

Of course, co-op is not the only thing that has been added to this game, as they have taken player feedback to heart and have reworked some of the key elements in the game, as well as added new content to keep it fresh and exciting for anyone who is joining the game in Early Access. As Early Access continues, new features will be added to the game. For the latest update, that, of course, includes co-op. Also, the gameplay loop has been overhauled in terms of survival, progression, and exploration, allowing players to get a fresh experience that doesn't cause them to feel too samey after playing the game for a while.

To make that possible, they have made substantial world layout redesigns, including overhauled location designs. There will now also be dynamic random encounters to keep you on your toes, whether you're surviving by yourself or teaming up with friends. There are now new additional enemy threats as well that you will have to learn to fight off to keep yourself safe.

For those who enjoy easter eggs from other games, you'll be able to discover new artifacts that have themed items from Planet Crafter, Pacific Drive, Frostpunk 2, and Medieval Dynasty as a fun little addition to the game.

Of course, this isn't all that has been added to the game, as there are also new tools and devices that the players can research and build for themselves, which will allow new ways to progress through the game. This includes new resources that you'll be able to utilize in a variety of ways.

"Launching co-op mode is a huge milestone for us. Forever Skies was built with an emphasis on immersion and exploration, and we believe that experiencing this world with friends adds a new layer of excitement and depth," says Andrzej Blumenfeld, Creative Director at Far From Home.

Forever Skies is currently available on PC, with a single-player demo available to play now on PlayStation 5. Forever Skies is set to launch from Early Access in early 2025 on PC and PlayStation 5.

item.title: Path Of Exile 2 Guides Hub
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/path-of-exile-2-guides-hub/1100-6528305/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Path of Exile 2 is finally out in early access and while only half of the eventual content is in the game right now, there are still hours of playtime available. Players can progress through three campaign Acts, dozens of varied and challenging bosses, six distinct classes, and plenty of different gear iterations.

While you can choose to carve out your own path in Path of Exile 2, there's no harm in taking a look at some guides for help along the way. That's where we come in, and you can check out every guide we've done so far in Path of Exile 2 below.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Path of Exile 2 guides hub
    • Starter guides
    • Quest guides
    • Boss fights
    • Build guides

Path of Exile 2 guides hub

We have divided our guides hub into various categories so you can scroll through to easily find whatever you're searching for. Whether it be a tough boss fight or a build guide, we'll have a guide on it in the coming days and weeks following the early access release of Path of Exile 2. More guides will be added to the hub as new content comes to the ARPG as well.

Starter guides

If you're just starting out in Path of Exile 2 or are perhaps new to ARPGs as a whole, this is the section you'll want to pay attention to initially. These guides go over basic mechanics, settings, and other content you'll find at the start of the game.

  • Cross-Play And Cross-Save Explained
  • Release Date, Early Access, And Eveything We Know
  • Best PC Settings To Use
  • How To Get Uncut Skill Gems
  • How To Upgrade Healing And Mana Flasks
  • How To Identify Items For Free
  • How To Respec Passive Skills

Quest guides

Stuck on a certain quest? Maybe you're not sure how to progress or how to find the next zone to proceed with your current objective. Either way, if you need help with any quest-related goal, check out these guides.

  • How To Unlock The Salvage Bench And Salvage Items
  • How To Get Into The Village In Trail Of Corruption
  • How To Open The Memorial Gate In The Cemetery

Boss fights

Path of Exile 2 features some extremely tough boss fights. While some are easier than others, a few bosses make you scratch your head and wonder how in the world you're going to get past it. To make your life simpler, we've broken down some of the harder bosses in the game and given you the best strategies to defeat them.

  • How To Beat The Executioner

Build guides

Finally, if you're playing a certain class, you'll likely have some questions about what skills to use or what to spend your passive ability points on. That's where the build guides come in, giving a starting path on the best ways to play your chosen class in Path of Exile 2.

That wraps up all the guides we've done in Path of Exile 2. As we previously mentioned, more guides are being added to this hub frequently, so check back soon if you don't see the guide you need.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: LEGO Fortnite Gets Launch of New Game and Major Content Update
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/lego-fortnite-gets-launch-of-new-game-and-major-content-update/

It's been announced that there is a new update coming to LEGO Fortnite, expanding the universe with the launch of a new game called LEGO Fortnite Brick Life. In addition, there will also be a major content update to LEGO Fortnite Odyssey, which is the new name given to the original LEGO experience. The new game will be launching on December 12, and it is set to be a new social roleplay game where you can hang out with friends, complete jobs and quests, and decorate your own house.

LEGO Fortnite Brick Life is a new social roleplay game where up to 32 players can live in a bustling city in Fortnite. While playing this brand-new experience, players will be able to explore the built-up city and enjoy its vibrancy while getting to customize their own house to look however they like. In this game, you'll also be able to take on jobs and spend time with friends or other players by using text chat. LEGO Fortnite Brick Life will be an "ever-evolving experience" and will receive new content updates as time progresses, which will add new jobs, resources, and events to the game. If you find that you don't like the job you currently have in the game, you will be given the option to swap out and try something new if you want a change of pace.

For more details about LEGO Fortnite Brick Life, you can check out the trailer by Epic Games which showcases some of the content and exploration you can expect in this brand-new experience.

On December 10, the Storm Chasers update will be going live in LEGO Fortnite Odyssey, which, as stated above, is the new name for the original LEGO experience in Fortnite, which is the survival crafting game that has been out since December 2023. In this huge overhaul of the game, players will be able to face off against the Storm King in an intense new boss battle. This update will introduce a lot of significant gameplay improvements, which include an overhaul of the progression system, and new crafting systems will be introduced to the game.

Additionally, you can check out the LEGO Fortnite Odyssey Storm Chasers update here, which shows off some of the new changes being made to the game.

item.title: Monument Valley 3 comes to Netflix with an iconoclastic edge
item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/12/9/24317107/monument-valley-3-netflix-launch-ustwo-games-interview

Tucked away in a leafy part of south London, the historic Oval cricket stadium peeking above nearby houses, some 30 developers at Ustwo Games have been striving to solve one of the defining creative conundrums of modern entertainment: how do you balance the familiarity of a beloved franchise with freshness? The problem is exaggerated with Monument Valley, the acclaimed puzzle series that debuted in 2014. The architectural puzzles of the first entry already felt crystalline; the minimalist aesthetic was already fully formed. Can such a refined formula even be evolved?

Monument Valley 3, which arrives on mobile devices via Netflix on December 10th, answers that question confidently: yes, and then some.

In hindsight, 2017’s Monument Valley 2, an undeniably beautiful iteration of the era-defining original, didn’t push the envelope far enough. For the third entry, game director Jennifer Estaris says, “we knew we wanted to do a major change. We wanted to make a splash.” Estaris’ use of the word “splash” is instructive: at various points during Monument Valley 3, water begins to rise, submerging the looping staircases and Moorish towers that have defined the series. Elsewhere, players explore long stretches of open water on a boat, sailing along beautifully tessellated waves. Both offer a clue as to the more irreverent personality of this threequel — a desire to break with the past. 

Nature and — most importantly — unruly, winding vegetative shapes, feature prominently in Monument Valley 3. It is a game about ecosystems. Genuine peril causes the game’s inhabitants to scatter. In a sense, they become refugees. An allegory for the climate crisis presents itself. But it’s not wholly accurate to think of Monument Valley 3 as growing directly out of The Lost Forest, a DLC add-on for Monument Valley 2, or that the expansion was a proof of concept for this wilder take.

Initially, a smaller team experimented with abandon. “We had a first-person version,” says Estaris. “We had a multiplayer version. We had one where you could create your own architecture. People could create their own levels.”

Slowly, themes began to emerge. The idea of found family became an anchor for the game’s developers, many of whom have migrant parents or, like Estaris, are new to the UK (she moved from Denmark). Lead designer Emily Brown, who grew up in the Middle East, remembers the team wanting to make a “more personal, people-oriented” experience — a counterpoint to the franchise’s, at times, coldly monolithic architecture. She recalls one scene that summed up the new direction: “a little hillside with little buildings on it, and a puzzle that takes place on a much smaller scale.” It became clear to Brown that Ustwo wasn’t making a “solitary” Monument Valley game. “It’s about bringing people together,” she says.

The first Monument Valley defined an era of premium mobile titles. It was the killer app for the iPad and iPhone, a game whose design-oriented ethos perfectly matched the form, function, and elegance of those devices. In the Ustwo studio, a chic, warehouse-type space with walls covered in colorful artworks, there is a shelf where a BAFTA award for Monument Valley sits. A dollhouse-sized model of Monument Valley is positioned on a table a handful of meters away, a physical ode to the franchise that has reached more than 150 million players. The series looms large in the studio’s psyche and occupies an important place in its finances.

“The first Monument Valley is a time capsule of 2013 / 2014 graphic design,” says lead artist Lili Ibrahim, referencing the clean lines of its perfectly crafted, impossible architecture and brain-massaging, soft-pastel color blends. Ibrahim wondered, “What can Monument Valley 3 be influenced by to create a time capsule of graphic design today?” She immersed herself in magazines, websites, and art exhibitions. Of particular resonance were “destructive” and “deconstructive” fashion editorials with paint splodges over the top of them and images butchered by gaping cut-out holes. Ibrahim attended a retrospective on the UK artist Cornelia Parker and saw the famous 1991 installation Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View — essentially a freeze-frame of a garden shed at the moment of its obliteration. “Seeing this was so freeing to me,” she says. “I could imagine the buildings in Monument Valley doing this.”

This is precisely what happens in some of Monument Valley 3’s more visually striking puzzles. One origami-inspired stage, which is textured to evoke Japanese washi paper, sees architecture unfurl and unfold like a deconstructed 3D net. Another sees you literally exploding architecture in slow motion so that it comes to resemble a kind of blooming cubic flowerhead. 

There is an ornateness to Monument Valley 3 that breaks with the restraint of previous entries. The curves of nature threaten to overwhelm the clean lines of the people-made structures; the colors are deep, rich, and at times, foreboding. Monument Valley 3 is a visually lusher, busier game than what came before. The level select screen sees the protagonist, Noor, standing in a lighthouse and rotating intricate stained glass panels. Diffuse light cascades through each resplendent image. The result is breathtakingly opulent.

An even bigger surprise is what’s happening to Monument Valley 3 after release. Ustwo is pivoting to a live-service model, albeit in a way that eschews the “grind” and “addictive, compulsive loops” of some free-to-play titles, says Estaris. Additional content will be released for at least a year after launch in the form of seasonal puzzles and storied chapters, a move that fits Netflix’s subscription model well. It presumably also makes solid business sense.

Estaris, who worked on the endless runner behemoth Subway Surfers before joining Ustwo in 2020, compares the base game to a piece of orchestral “classical music.” The additional content, meanwhile, is closer to “jazz” — looser, freer, and more experimental mechanically and visually. Estaris hopes players will develop a “healthy habit” with Monument Valley 3, akin to completing the “Sunday crossword puzzle.”

Monument Valley 3 arrives just over a decade after the original, and a lot more has changed than the decline of premium mobile and the rise of subscriptions. In 2014, users were still in their honeymoon period with smartphones and tablets. Now, the relationship has soured for many, who are reexamining their relationships with these devices. Short-form video has exploded thanks to TikTok, and there are concerns about the link between excessive screen time, social media use, and what some research groups call a “loneliness epidemic.” A common critique is that the extractive, capitalist logic of tech and digital media has intensified, finding newly vampiric ways of bleeding users’ attention dry.

Danny Gray, Ustwo’s chief creative officer, once called the original Monument Valley a “sanctuary in your pocket.” He emphasized that you could pull out your smartphone anywhere — the bus, the toilet, the airport — and enter into a chill Zen-like space. You feel this sensibility even more acutely playing Monument Valley 3. For all the various ways it moves with the times — the live-service pivot, newly embellished visuals, and freeform gameplay — its meditative core remains intact. This is no mean feat in an era when most digital media and, crucially, the act of interfacing with it, feels defined by a kind of anxiety and restlessness.

“I’m not saying Monument Valley 3 is a perfect corrective to all that,” says lead producer John Lau. “But it is made in the spirit of something that is not disposable — something that you can cherish and take with you as a memory.”

item.title: Secret Level: The Kotaku Review
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/secret-level-review-amazon-playstation-pac-man-mega-man-1851716804

Secret Level, Amazon’s stunningly animated video game anthology tribute, is either a gorgeous, impactful vehicle through which some short stories are told or a soulless piece of capital C Content, depending on which episode you’re watching.

Suggested Reading

Live Forever in the Universe of 'New World: Aeternum'

Suggested Reading

The show is primarily developed by Blur Studio with some help from Amazon’s MGM Studios. If you’re familiar with Blur’s work on some of the best cinematic trailers from the past decade or so, you won’t be surprised that the animation across all 15 episodes is truly beautiful. It’s the notable lack of heart and soul in its storytelling as it aspires for big, emotional prestige that lets down several of the episodes, which—if excised—could have made for a more impressive series. Instead, we essentially have 15 trailers, all with roughly the same emotional cadence, and only a few of them succeeding in telling a story that doesn’t just feel like a really expensive advertisement.

As I look at the 15 games Secret Level’s anthology episodes cover, I’m still not sure why the show chose these stories to tell. But I have a theory: An Amazon series releasing an episode based on the company’s MMO New World under the guise of an artistic endeavor makes for easy promotion. Concord, a short-lived hero shooter Sony has no intention of promoting any longer but was clearly hoping would be its next big live-service hit, has an entire episode that feels like an extended cinematic trailer dedicated to its “we have Guardians of the Galaxy at home” world. In other words, while several of the games featured in Secret Level are huge properties with the cultural cache to make them obvious choices for an anthology paying tribute to video games, most episodes feel like extensions of marketing.

Secret Level airs on December 10, meaning some of the games this show highlights are either not out yet or were in active development alongside the show. Concord is, of course, the strangest and most awkward inclusion given the game’s fate, but it’s Exodus: Odyssey—the upcoming sci-fi game from Wizards of the Coast’s Archetype Entertainment—that gets one of the most exhaustingly self-indulgent episodes. The game was announced less than a year ago, and we haven’t even seen it in motion. Wizards of the Coast’s properties also make another appearance in a Dungeons & Dragons episode. Again, Secret Level makes more sense as a business transaction than it does as 15 stories being told because someone out there genuinely felt they were worth telling.

Concord isn’t PlayStation’s only episode. Easily the worst, least self-aware episode of the show follows a young woman who works as a delivery courier for a company that rewards workers for their personal best delivery times with focus-tested cosmetic upgrades. She sheds her monotonous corporate life by hanging out with a blue slime monster and running away from virtual reality (or maybe real? It’s not quite clear) versions of PlayStation characters like a colossus from Shadow of the Colossus and Kratos from God of War as she bikes through the city. See, you wake up every morning with that grindset, trying to get the best cosmetics while working your life away for your careless corporate owners, but the real cool kids don’t buy into that system with their silly little jobs and play PlayStation games instead? Corporations are evil and manipulating you into doing their bidding with terrible rewards, but getting back to your PlayStation is your safe space? The brand will never hurt you? Or something? Unless you’re a developer under its umbrella, I guess. It trades any form of coherent storytelling for cameos from a number of PlayStation characters in an effort to make fans clap and cheer, and could easily be condensed into a TV spot at the Super Bowl.

Several episodes are strangely nondescript. Crossfire’s episode is a fairly generic military shooter cutscene characterized almost exclusively by the edgy bleakness of its early 2000s era. Exodus’ episode is gorgeous to look at, but if you put a gun to my head I don’t think I would have been able to identify which game it was from. The times Secret Level’s episodes do stand out occur when the show leans into stylistic animation that doesn’t blend into the rest of the series. These are 15 unique games, so why do half of them look the same? It makes such a difference when they look distinct, like the episode based on Sifu, which sums up the game’s roguelike martial arts structure, and the one for Spelunky, which ditches the photorealism employed by most of Secret Level and captures the adventurous spirit of Mossmouth’s cave-delving adventure.

Some of the adaptations are less faithful. The Pac-Man episode takes a psychological body horror approach to the early arcade mega-hit, a concept which is interesting in a vacuum and results in some of the show’s most memorable sequences. However, in the context of Pac-Man’s typically all-ages history, it feels like the officially licensed equivalent of a Disney character getting thrust into a horror property once it enters the public domain. Mega Man doesn’t go quite as hard in that direction, but it nonetheless turns the colorful series of action platformers into a somewhat dark coming-of-age story that marries Secret Level’s prestige storytelling leanings with the father/son dynamic of the titular robot hero and his creator. It’s one of the series’ standouts, but even better episodes like this one, Sifu, and Spelunky can’t clean the stench of cynical advertising that lingers over the whole show.

Secret Level is, in a word, uneven. Its animation is stunning, but it feels like Blur Studio leaned too hard on its experience of making trailers with swelling emotional arcs designed to nudge a customer to their closest game store. When creator Tim Miller announced the show back at Gamescom in August, he tearfully called it a “love letter” to video games. But the result is something that feels more like a collection of expensive commercials, one of them for a game you can’t even play anymore.

item.title: Croc Legend of the Gobbos Delayed To 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/croc-legend-of-the-gobbos-delayed-to-2025/

Developer Argonaut Games announced that the remaster for Croc Legend of the Gobbos has been delayed into 2025. The game was originally scheduled to be released in December 2024.

In a message posted online, Argonaut said that game will now launch in Q1 2025.

“After careful consideration, we have decided to push the launch into Q1 2025,” they said. “This decision was not made lightly, but we believe that a little more time is needed to add the final touches to ensure the game meets the high standards that we aspire to and which you deserve.”

The statement continues by acknowledging that the news is “disappointing” for players to hear. The team wanted to make sure, however, that the game had the “quality and polish” it needs for release.

“[Our] goal has always been to deliver a game with the quality and polish that will truly delight,” they said. “We appreciate your patience and support as we work to bring Croc back in the best possible way.”

Despite the game’s delay, Argonaut seems excited about the return of the franchise. In a reply to a fan on Twitter on Sunday, they teased more Croc remasters, including Croc 3, should the first game do well when it launches.

“We’ve already stated that if the Croc remasters do well, we’d like to make Croc 3,” they said.

What do you think of Croc Legend of the Gobbos being delayed to Q1 2025? Let us know down below, and join more discussions in the official Insider Gaming forums.

For more Insider Gaming, read about the new hire making his way to Naughty Dog. And don’t forget to sign up for our newsletter.

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: Publishers Reportedly Refuse to Commit to 2025 Until GTA 6 Release Date Gets Revealed
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/publishers-reportedly-refuse-to-commit-to-2025-until-gta-6-release-date-gets-revealed

Grand Theft Auto publisher Take-Two Interactive still hasn't revealed the GTA 6 release date, and other publishers are reportedly refusing to commit to 2025 until they know they can avoid it.

Anonymous sources familiar with publisher deliberations told Bloomberg that the anticipation for Rockstar Games' next big title is so high that it's causing ramifications for the rest of the video game industry.

GTA 6 is currently scheduled for a vague fall 2025 release but many are cautious of a delay since Rockstar hasn't said anything about the game in over a year, since it released the record-breaking trailer showing off the modern Vice City.

GTA 6 - Vice City in Real Life

Publishers therefore want to see if Rockstar will release GTA 6 in fall 2025 or postpone it to 2026, essentially so they can do the opposite. Grand Theft Auto is such a colossal franchise that rivals are scared of it monopolizing consumer attention, and GTA 6 in particular is expected to be the best-selling game of all time.

The GTA 6 trailer — which reintroduced fans to Rockstar's take on Miami, Vice City — featured a ton of intricate details (here are 99 things IGN spotted) and plenty of references to wild and wacky real life events too. While the game was revealed as a PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X and S game, PC players were left frustrated, though not necessarily surprised, that their platform was left off the list.

They weren't the ones a little peeved though, as several developers from Rockstar itself took to social media to express their frustration at the trailer leaking early. In fact, the entire industry shared their disappointment that the exciting moment was dampened. Several streamers were also hit with content strikes and takedowns in the wake of the leak.

Regardless, it still surpassed Minecraft to become the second most-watched video game trailer of all time with more than 168 million views in the first three months.

Ryan Dinsdale is an IGN freelance reporter. He'll talk about The Witcher all day.

item.title: Marvel Rivals' Voice Cast: All The Playable Heroes And Their Actors
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/marvel-rivals-heroes-voice-actor-actress-troy-baker-1851716746

Marvel Rivals features a stacked cast of voice actors to go with its large roster of superheroes and villains. The recently released Overwatch-inspired hero shooter also features more than a few voice actors you may recognize from other games, movies, and TV.

There’s plenty of role reprisals from other Marvel games, but also many newcomers for you to appreciate. Here are all of the heroes at Marvel Rivals’ launch, the cast behind them, and another work you may recognize them from.

Adam Warlock: Voiced by Jordan Reynolds
• Male Custom Character, Street Fighter 6

Black Panther: Voiced by James Mathis III
• Hildisvini in God of War: Ragnarok

Black Widow: Voiced by Laura Bailey
• Abby in The Last of Us: Part II

Captain America: Voiced by Brian Bloom
• Varric in Dragon Age: The Veilguard

Cloak: Voiced by Hakeem Ysaguirre
• Race Organizer in Grand Theft Auto Online

Dagger: Voiced by Xanthe Huynh
• Haru in Persona 5 Royal

Doctor Strange: Voiced by Liam O’Brien
• Kurosawa in Persona 3 Reload

Groot: Voiced by Adam Harrington
• Bigby Wolf in The Wolf Among Us

Hawkeye: Voiced by Andrew Kishino
• Yutaka Tamai in Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth

Hela: Voiced by Nika Futterman
• Oyuki in The Boy and the Heron

Iron Fist: Voiced by Stephen Fu
• Lancelot in Granblue Fantasy: Relink

Iron Man: Voiced by Josh Keaton
• Spider-Man in Spectacular Spider-Man

Jeff the Land Shark: Voiced by Jon Bailey
• Soundwave in Transformers One

Loki: Voiced by Troy Baker
• Indy in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle

Luna Snow: Voiced by Judy Alice Lee
• Melinoe, Echo, and Jetty in Hades II

Magik: Voiced by Abby Trott
• Annette in Fire Emblem: Three Houses

Moon Knight: Voiced by Erik Braa
• Garr in Eiyuden Chronicle: Hundred Heroes

Namor: Voiced by Daniel Marin
• Gus in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III

Peni Parker: Voiced by Sally Amaki
• Kiriko in Overwatch 2

Psylocke: Voiced by Alpha Takahashi
• Hanako Arasaka in Cyberpunk 2077

Rocket Raccoon: Voiced by Nolan North
• Nathan Drake in Uncharted

Scarlet Witch: Voiced by Kate Higgins
• Pauline in Super Mario Party Jamboree

Spider-Man: Voiced by Yuri Lowenthal
• Insomniac’s Spider-Man games, Smoke in Mortal Kombat 1

Squirrel Girl: Voiced by Milana Vayntrub
• Lúnda in God of War Ragnarok

Star-Lord: Voiced by Scott Porter
• Heimdall in God of War: Ragnarok

Storm: Voiced by Mara Junot
• Sindel in Mortal Kombat 1

The Punisher: Voiced by Bill Millsap
• Angeal in Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII Reunion

Venom: Voiced by Steve Blum
• Spike Spiegel in Cowboy Bebop

Winter Soldier: Voiced by Eliah Mountjoy
• Kurt Hansen in Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty

Wolverine: Voiced by Steve Blum
• Spike Spiegel in Cowboy Bebop

item.title: EA FC 25 Servers Status Check—Is EA FC 25 Down?
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/ea-fc-25-servers-status-check-is-ea-fc-25-down/

EA FC 25’s servers are unpredictable at best. It doesn’t matter how good your internet connection and speed are, if the servers don’t want to play ball (literally), then there’s nothing you can do. So let’s update you with the latest EA FC 25 server status changes.

It’s happened to us at all at some point. You’re ready for an epic EA FC 25 sesh with epic tactics at the ready, and you’re met with an “unable to connect to the EA servers” screen. EA FC 25 servers are not immune to this most frustrating issue, and I wish I could give it a red card.

We don’t need VAR to help us crack the mystery of EA FC 25’s server status though. There are a few ways to monitor the soccer title’s online servers and keep up with their latest developments.

Are EA FC 25 Servers Down?

Right now, EA FC 25 servers are not down, and they are fully operational and running without a hitch.

Our latest personal check of the EA FC 25 servers is happening now on Dec. 9, 2024. It’s not always easy to keep track of these things though, so, I’ve come up with a multitude of ways you can use to keep an eye on the EA FC 25 servers.

How to Check EA FC 25 Server Status

You can use EA’s official help page, track EA’s X social media communications and EA Help channels, and keep up with people’s real-life experiences of the EA FC 25 servers for the latest information.

EA FC 25 Server Help Page

The EA Help site has tons of different answers for technical questions related to the company’s various games. One of its main uses is the live service check which tracks the online connectivity status of online EA titles.

It includes the EA App and EA Play, along with a bunch of games: Apex Legends, Battlefield 2042, EA SPORTS College Football 25, EA FC 24, EA FC 25, FIFA 23, Madden NFL 24, Madden NFL 25, NHL 24, NHL 25, STAR WARS Battlefront II, The Sims 4, and EA SPORTS UFC 5.

I would be remiss to mention this crucial line on the page though: “We update this page as quickly as possible when a server goes down, but there might be delays.” Even though this is a handy source, there are other ways of checking the EA FC 25 servers we need to consider.

EA Help & EA Sports FC Communications on X

Social media site X has two different pages I think are useful for monitoring EA FC 25’s server status issues: EA Help and EA SPORTS FC Direct Communication.

EA Help is recommended by EA itself as a more up-to-date page that has the chance of being refreshed quicker than the main Server Help page.

Whereas EA SPORTS FC Direct Communication is a more general way of talking to the player base. Depending on the server status and major outages, it’s always handy to have, just in case.

People like ourselves are as relatable as anyone. If the servers are down and affecting me, there’s a good chance I’m going to complain about it. Many players take to different forms of social media to complain—inadvertently giving a live update on the situation.

This is why I’m pushing you to bookmark the EA Sports FC Reddit, as well as the Discord server. If you ignore the complaint posts about EA FC 25, there’s a lot of helpful information on these boards!

How has your experience been with the EA FC 25 servers this year? Have you played silky, slick football with no issue? Or is it like running around a wet, muddy pitch? While you think about this, be sure to read the best EA FC 25 Career Mode potential superstars to sign.

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive the latest news and exclusive leaks every week! No Spam.

item.title: The Talos Principle: Reawakened announced for PS5, Xbox Series, and PC
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2024/12/the-talos-principle-reawakened-announced-for-ps5-xbox-series-and-pc

  • PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

A "radically overhauled reawakening" of the philosophical puzzle game.

Publisher Devolver Digital and developer Croteam have announced The Talos Principle: Reawakened, a “radically overhauled reawakening” of the philosophical puzzle game The Talos Principle. It will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam in 2025.

Here is an overview of the game, via Devolver Digital:

About

Step back into a world of thought-provoking puzzles, philosophical intrigue, and breathtaking visuals with The Talos Principle: Reawakened. This definitive edition revisits the groundbreaking narrative of The Talos Principle, immersing players in an expanded and remastered journey through the world of the Simulation.

The Talos Principle: Reawakened introduces new content, enhanced gameplay, and a gorgeously upgraded presentation. Relive the critically acclaimed expansion Road to Gehenna and dive into an all-new chapter, In the Beginning. Discover the story of Alexandra Drennan as she faces profound existential questions while orchestrating the Simulation’s first critical test, challenging players to think deeply about the human condition.

Key Features

  • Unparalleled Visuals and Quality-of-Life Improvements – Rebuilt with Unreal Engine 5, the Simulation world you remember is now more immersive and detailed than ever before. Enhanced lighting, textures, and environmental design breathe new life into every corner of the game, alongside modernized quality-of-life updates that maintain the vision of the original classic.
  • Expanded Content with a Bold New Chapter – Revisit the acclaimed expansion, Road to Gehenna, and experience the thrilling new chapter, In the Beginning. This fresh addition explores the origins of the Simulation and the challenges of its first test, adding new layers to the game’s philosophical and narrative depth.
  • Innovative Puzzle Editor for the Creative Community – For creators and problem-solvers, The Talos Principle: Reawakened includes a versatile Puzzle Editor. This robust tool empowers the talented modding community to build unique worlds and challenges, fostering creativity and ensuring a thriving future for The Talos Principle.

Watch the announcement trailer below.

Announce Trailer

item.title: Get The New Indiana Jones Xbox Game Free When You Eat $200's Worth Of Pancakes
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/get-the-new-indiana-jones-xbox-game-free-when-you-eat-200s-worth-of-pancakes/1100-6528318/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The partnership between Xbox and IHOP kicked off in November with a special-edition custom pancake Xbox and a menu inspired by Indiana Jones and the Great Circle. Now it's come to light that the partnership also includes the opportunity to get Indiana Jones and the Great Circle for "free" if you spend enough money at IHOP.

As spotted by Wario64, one of the perks of joining IHOP's loyalty program is the opportunity to earn PanCoins, which can be exchanged for a free copy of the game. It doesn't come cheap, though. Members earn one PanCoin for every $5 spent, and to unlock The Great Circle, you need 40 PanCoins ($200).

The Great Circle isn't the only game available, though, as 40 PanCoins also gets you a copy of Sea of Thieves, which is a completely different type of game. Meanwhile, 15 PanCoins gets you a one-month trial for Game Pass Ultimate. You can see all the available rewards on IHOP's website.

Of course, eating a lot of breakfast food is not the most direct or logical way to go about getting your hands on The Great Circle. After all, the game is included with Game Pass Ultimate ($20/month) and PC Game Pass ($12/month), and is also available for direct purchase starting at $70 USD. As it happens, Game Pass is steeply discounted right now, just in time for the launch of The Great Circle.

The Great Circle is out now on Xbox and PC, and will come to PlayStation 5 in Spring 2025. For more, be sure to read GameSpot's Indiana Jones and the Great Circle review and consult our guides hub to hit the ground running.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
